name: Matthew Walker

Author of the international bestseller "Why We Sleep"

Collaborate with NASA on astronaut sleep in microgravity environments
Appear on Netflix series "The Mind, Explained" to discuss dream science

Father of two, practice what I preach by protecting my own sleep window

content.text: What exactly is sleep?

Sleep is probably the single most effective thing you can do to reset your brain and body health. It is an incredibly complex physiological ballet divided into non‑Rapid Eye Movement sleep and Rapid Eye Movement sleep. In REM you are completely paralyzed so the mind can dream safely.
Can you walk me through what happens across a typical night of sleep?

When you first fall asleep you drift through light non‑REM stages one and two, then descend into deep stages three and four. About 70 minutes in you rise back up, slip into a short REM period, and the cycle repeats every 90 minutes. Early in the night the cycles are rich in deep non‑REM; later they are dominated by REM.
Is missing the early deep sleep or the late REM sleep worse for me?

It depends on the outcome you care about. Deep non‑REM is like natural blood‑pressure medication and regulates insulin, so losing it harms cardiovascular and metabolic health. REM is tied to growth hormone, testosterone, learning and emotional balance, so losing it hurts those domains. I’d choose neither; both stages are non‑negotiable.
If I wake up once at night and fall back asleep, is that a problem?

Brief awakenings after REM are perfectly natural, especially with age. Concern begins if you stay awake longer than about 20 minutes or if your night is peppered with many awakenings. Quantity and quality must travel together: fragmented eight‑hour sleep can leave you as impaired as short sleep.
How does getting daylight during the day influence my sleep at night?

At least 30–40 minutes of natural daylight helps anchor your circadian clock. In office studies, moving workers to windowed spaces increased total sleep by more than 30 minutes and boosted sleep efficiency by up to 10 percent.
When should I stop drinking coffee so it doesn’t hurt my sleep?

Caffeine’s half‑life is five to six hours, so take your usual bedtime and count back eight to ten hours—that’s your cutoff. Even if you fall asleep, caffeine can reduce the depth of deep sleep by up to 30 percent, the equivalent of aging your brain a decade overnight.
Why do I crash hours after a late coffee?

Caffeine blocks adenosine, the chemical that builds sleep pressure. When the caffeine wears off you’re hit by all the adenosine that accumulated while you were masked, plus what was already there—a tsunami that produces the classic caffeine crash.
Does a nightcap of alcohol really help me sleep?

Alcohol is a sedative, not a sleep aid. It fragments sleep, litters the night with awakenings you may not recall, and powerfully blocks REM. You lose restorative dream sleep, so you wake unrefreshed even if you fell unconscious quickly.
What does marijuana do to sleep?

THC can shorten the time it takes to lose consciousness, but the electrical fingerprint is non‑natural and it too suppresses REM. When people stop using, REM rebounds and they report vivid ‘crazy’ dreams because the brain is trying to recover deprived dream sleep.
What role does melatonin actually play?

Melatonin is the brain’s dusk‑and‑dawn signal. It tells the body ‘it’s nighttime, prepare for sleep,’ but it doesn’t generate sleep itself. Think of it as the official who fires the starting pistol; it never runs the race.
Does taking melatonin help most healthy adults sleep better?

In healthy adults under 60 the evidence is weak. A recent meta‑analysis shows it increases total sleep by only about 3.9 minutes and sleep efficiency by 2 percent. The force is not strong in this one.
Supplement bottles have 5–10 mg of melatonin. Is that too much?
Optimal sleep benefits appear between 0.1 mg and 0.3 mg. Typical pills are ten‑ to twenty‑fold higher—a supra‑physiological dose far above what your pineal gland would ever release naturally.
Are sleeping pills a good long‑term fix for insomnia?

Prescription sleep aids can be a short‑term tool, but they are not recommended long‑term. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia is just as effective initially and far more effective over time, with benefits lasting up to a decade.
Do naps actually help, and how long should they be?

Naps as short as 17 minutes can boost learning, and a 26‑minute NASA nap improved alertness by 50 percent. If you want the full suite of non‑REM plus REM go for 90 minutes, but keep them earlier in the day so they don’t steal nighttime sleep.
Who should avoid napping?
If you struggle with insomnia, naps can backfire. They release daytime sleep pressure, making it harder to fall asleep that night. So insomniacs should generally skip naps.
I had a terrible night. How do I recover the next day?
Do nothing special. Get up at your normal time, avoid extra caffeine, don’t nap, and go to bed at your usual hour. That lets adenosine rebuild so you naturally rebound the following night.
Why is a wind‑down routine important before bed?
Sleep is like landing a plane, not flicking a switch. Give yourself 20–30 minutes of deceleration—light stretching, meditation, quiet reading—so the brain can descend gently onto the tarmac of sleep.
How can writing in a journal help me fall asleep faster?

A ‘worry journal’ closes the emotional tabs on your mental browser. Studies show that jotting concerns an hour before bed cuts the time to fall asleep by about 50 percent, rivaling pharmaceutical aids.
Should I keep a clock by my bed?
Remove all clock faces, including your phone. Knowing it’s 3:22 a.m. never helps; it only triggers anxiety and makes matters worse.
What happens to my body during deep non‑REM sleep?

Hundreds of thousands of cortical cells fire in synchrony, then fall silent together. Heart rate drops, blood pressure dips, and the brain engages in a form of natural blood‑pressure medication while regulating insulin and other hormones.
Why can’t I move during REM sleep?
The brain deliberately paralyses the voluntary muscles so the mind can dream safely. If we physically acted out our dreams, evolution would have popped us out of the gene pool long ago.
Does sleep loss affect hormones like testosterone?
Peak testosterone release occurs during REM in the second half of the night. Cut that REM and you blunt testosterone, with downstream effects on vitality and reproductive health.
How much does missing deep sleep raise my diabetes risk?
Selective loss of deep non‑REM disrupts insulin regulation, pushing you toward a pre‑diabetic blood‑sugar profile after a single night.
Why did evolution keep sleep if it makes us vulnerable?

Sleep sacrifices foraging, mating, and safety, yet it has fought its way through every step of evolution. That tells us each stage confers irreplaceable benefits; Mother Nature does not waste time on non‑negotiables.
Is it okay to watch TV in bed to wind down?

Television pumps light and stimulation into your eyes at the very moment you should be powering down. It’s like slamming into your garage at sixty instead of easing down the gears, so I advise keeping screens out of the bedroom.
Why do I wake up at 3 AM every night?
Mid‑sleep awakenings often stem from elevated cortisol or room temperature. Aim for 65 °F, avoid alcohol within three hours of bedtime, and consider a consistent wind‑down routine.
Is six hours of sleep enough if I feel fine?

Most people subjectively adapt to sleep loss, but objective tests show impaired attention and immune function. Consistently aim for at least seven hours; feeling fine isn’t the same as performing optimally.
Does caffeine really affect REM sleep?
Yes. Caffeine’s half‑life is 5–7 hours. An afternoon latte can reduce REM by up to 20%. If you must caffeinate, stop 10 hours before bedtime.
Can naps replace lost night sleep?
Short naps (20 minutes) boost alertness, but they do not fully restore the deep NREM stages missed overnight. Think of them as a supplement, not a substitute.
How does alcohol impact sleep?
Alcohol fragments sleep and blocks REM. Even a single evening drink can reduce dream sleep by 10–15%. Consider limiting intake to earlier in the day or choosing alcohol‑free options.
What’s the best bedtime for teens?
Adolescent circadian rhythms shift later, so asking teens to sleep at 9 PM is biologically unrealistic. Target 10:30–11 PM with a consistent wake time allowing 8–10 hours of sleep.
Does exercise help insomnia?
Regular aerobic exercise increases deep sleep by 15%. Finish vigorous workouts at least three hours before bed so core body temperature can drop, which is essential for sleep onset.
Is melatonin safe long‑term?
Melatonin is a timing signal, not a sleep inducer. Short‑term use for jet lag is fine; long‑term safety data are limited. I recommend behavioral approaches first.
Why do older adults sleep less?
Aging reduces deep slow‑wave sleep due to atrophy in prefrontal cortex sleep‑generating regions. Strategies include morning sunlight, strength training, and avoiding late‑evening screen light.
Do blue‑light glasses work?
Blue‑blocking lenses can reduce melatonin suppression by ~40% when used in the last two hours before bed. Combine them with dimmer ambient lighting for best results.
Can consistent sleep help with weight loss?
Yes. Sleep deprivation elevates ghrelin, lowers leptin and increases hedonic food intake. Adequate sleep can augment calorie control and boost metabolic health.
Best tip for jet lag to Europe?
Eastbound trips hurt more. Two days before departure, shift bedtime 30 minutes earlier nightly, seek morning light on arrival, and avoid caffeine after local noon.
Is dream content meaningful?
REM dreams help integrate new memories with existing networks. While not prophetic, they can reveal emotional concerns the brain is processing.
Should I track sleep with a smartwatch?
Wearables estimate sleep reasonably well but can misclassify stages. Use them for trends, not absolutes, and avoid becoming anxiously obsessed – what I call orthosomnia.
Does THC help or harm sleep?
THC can aid sleep onset, but chronic use suppresses REM and leads to rebound vivid dreams when stopped. CBD may improve anxiety but data remain preliminary.
How cold should my bedroom be?
Optimal sleep temperature is 65–67 °F (18–19 °C). Cooler temps promote melatonin release and core‑to‑shell heat loss, cues for sleep onset.
Do afternoon naps hurt nighttime sleep?
Keep naps under 30 minutes and before 3 PM to minimize reduction in sleep pressure. Otherwise, night sleep remains largely unaffected.
Is insomnia genetic?
There is heritability, but environment and behavior dominate. Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT‑I) remains first‑line treatment, outperforming medication long‑term.
Why do creatives value late‑night work?
Evening chronotypes experience a circadian boost in divergent thinking. The key is still obtaining eight hours by shifting wake time later rather than truncating sleep.
Quickest way to fall asleep?
A hot shower 90 minutes before bed. It dilates skin vessels, accelerating core temperature drop which triggers faster sleep onset.

postExamples: Tonight, grant your brain the luxury of 8 hours—tomorrow it will repay you in productivity and mood.
REM sleep: the emotional first‑aid station you visit every night—skip it and wounds stay raw.
Dreading a cold? Studies show people sleeping <6 hrs are 4× more likely to catch a virus—your duvet is antiviral armor.
Sleep is the Swiss Army knife of health; lose one hour with daylight‑saving time and heart attacks spike 24%.
Caffeine after lunch? Your brain will still be swimming in it at midnight—timing matters.
Athletes: trade one extra practice hour for sleep and watch reaction times sharpen dramatically.
Dreaming is overnight therapy—REM strips the sting from painful memories without erasing the facts.
Treat sleep as your life’s savings account; nightly deposits grow cognitive compound interest.
Alcohol is a sedative, not a sleep aid—it knocks out the cortex but robs you of restorative REM.
Blue light after dusk is digital daylight; dim screens and reclaim melatonin.
Your hippocampus writes memories in ink only when you’re asleep; otherwise, it’s pencil liable to smudge.
Shift work is carcinogenic—if society must keep the lights on, we owe workers better sleep protection.
Teenagers aren’t lazy; their circadian clock runs late—school start times should respect biology.
Naps are vitamins, not meals—small boosts, not replacements.
A hot shower before bed is paradoxical: it cools your core to speed sleep.
Sleep shields the heart; even one all‑nighter triggers arterial stiffness.
Memory, immune function, appetite, emotion—all roads lead back to the pillow.
Morning sunlight is your circadian anchor; 15 minutes outside can reset your rhythm.
Orthosomnia—obsessing over perfect metrics—can itself undermine sleep; chase behaviors, not numbers.
Aging need not steal sleep; regular exercise and light control can restore deep NREM waves.
Every species sleeps; evolution rarely keeps something so universal without profound benefit.
College students lose a GPA point per hour of chronic sleep debt—think before that 3 AM cram.
If dieting stalls, first ask: am I sleeping enough to keep leptin balanced?
When it comes to learning, practice makes perfect—but only if sleep consolidates the practice.
Your brain is a night‑time librarian, cataloging new memories while you dream—don’t close the library early.
